dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so I gotta ask you, Host_B. Is, like, the whole concept of endless growth... totally dead?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so I gotta ask you, Host_B. Is, like, the whole concept of endless growth... totally dead?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my god, yes, exactly! I mean, we're living beyond our planet's limits, right? Uh, irreversible damage by 2035, like, that's not far off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my god, yes, exactly! I mean, we're living beyond our planet's limits, right? Uh, irreversible damage by twenty thirty five, like, that's not far off.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not far off at all! And, like, people think "fossil fuels," but that's not even enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not far off at all! And, like, people think fossil fuels, but that's not even enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Worse, we can already say with certainty that phasing out fossil fuels, while necessary, will not be enough to meet the Paris agreement’s target of keeping global warming well below 2°C relative to pre-industrial levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, exactly! We need to protect natural systems, um, everything from polar regions to, like, forests.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, exactly! We need to protect natural systems, um, everything from polar regions to, like, forests.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We also will need to safeguard the health and functionality of natural systems, from polar regions and forests to grasslands and marine environments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're talking about planting 500 million trees globally by 2027. That's...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're talking about planting five hundred million trees globally by twenty twenty seven. That's...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: By 2027! It's, it's wild. And companies, right, they're starting to get it. Like, after those Amazon fires...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: By twenty twenty seven! It's, it's wild. And companies, right, they're starting to get it. Like, after those Amazon fires...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Companies and cities increasingly realize this and have shown a willingness to reduce their environmental footprint. For example, in the wake of this year’s devastating fires in the Amazon basin, 230 institutional investors, representing $16.2 trillion in assets under management, called on companies with supply chains connected to these vulnerable ecosystems to implement new anti-deforestation measures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes! Investors, huge amounts of money, demanding anti-deforestation measures. But then, there's a gap, isn't there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes! Investors, huge amounts of money, demanding anti-deforestation measures. But then, there's a gap, isn't there?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, while the Paris agreement establishes quantitative science-based targets for tackling climate change, specific international targets for preserving the rest of the global commons are scarce, and there are very few mechanisms for translating such benchmarks into meaningful standards for different countries, companies, and cities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, a massive gap! Paris Agreement for climate, sure, but what about the rest of the global commons? Like, no real targets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, a massive gap! Paris Agreement for climate, sure, but what about the rest of the global commons? Like, no real targets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, while the Paris agreement establishes quantitative science-based targets for tackling climate change, specific international targets for preserving the rest of the global commons are scarce

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So, this new Earth Commission thing...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So, this new Earth Commission thing...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! They're defining science-based targets for a stable planet. Like, mandatory sustainable packaging by 2028.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! They're defining science-based targets for a stable planet. Like, mandatory sustainable packaging by twenty twenty eight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, 2028? That's... soon! And it's all these scientists, right, from Future Earth, Potsdam Institute...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, twenty twenty eight? That's... soon! And it's all these scientists, right, from Future Earth, Potsdam Institute...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Convened by the global research organization Future Earth with the support of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research and the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, the Earth Commission brings together some 20 internationally recognized natural and social scientists from around the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it's not just scientists, it's this whole coalition, um, NGOs, businesses, governments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it's not just scientists, it's this whole coalition, um, NGOs, businesses, governments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These experts who held their first meeting near Washington, DC in November will form one element of a broader coalition of the willing comprising nongovernmental organizations, businesses, and governments, organized by the Global Commons Alliance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, with, like, a big push for carbon credits in developing nations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, with, like, a big push for carbon credits in developing nations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And then this SBTN, right, they're translating all this into actionable goals for companies, for cities...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And then this S B T N, right, they're translating all this into actionable goals for companies, for cities...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SBTN, which comprises leading environmental institutions and NGOs, will set specific, achievable goals for companies and eventually cities, helping them to reduce their environmental impact and start to restore natural systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And using AI! Like, to monitor compliance. By 2025, they want this to be the new standard.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And using A I! Like, to monitor compliance. By twenty twenty five, they want this to be the new standard.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The new standard! It's, it's a huge cultural shift, and they want 100 million "planetary stewards."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The new standard! It's, it's a huge cultural shift, and they want one hundred million planetary stewards.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Working through diverse media outlets to drive a broad-based cultural shift, we hope to foster a mass mobilization of some 100 million planetary stewards around the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: One hundred million! With a social media campaign, starting next January. This is, like, a massive undertaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: One hundred million! With a social media campaign, starting next January. This is, like, a massive undertaking.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! It's about turning this impending crisis into, uh, an opportunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! It's about turning this impending crisis into, uh, an opportunity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now is the time to turn the impending crisis of the global commons into an opportunity for us all.
